titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Gladys Campbell Papers
titlestmt.author: by Molly Wheeler

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 05:06

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Gladys Campbell Papers contain correspondence, writings, and other papers that document the work of the poet Gladys Campbell and other members of the University of Chicago Poetry Club, as well as her relationships with other poets. The papers also contain writings of George Dillon, Charles Bell, Janet Lewis, Maurice Lesemann, Naomi Clark, and Morton Zabel. The papers span the years 1914 to 1995.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Serendipity Books on the Elizabeth Wakeman Dwight Memorial Fund, 2003.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Gladys Campbell Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Gladys Campbell Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: Gladys Campbell
bioghist.p: Gladys Campbell (1892-1992) attended the University of Chicago to study poetry and earned a Bachelor of Arts in 1920 and a Master of Arts in 1943. Campbell was one of the early members of the University of Chicago Poetry Club, a group formed in 1917 by students who wished to address the absence of modern poetry in the University curriculum. Other members included Glenway Wescott, George Dillon, Elizabeth Madox Roberts, Arthur Yvor Winters, Llewellyn Jones, Maurice Lesemann, and Janet Lewis. Harriet Monroe, the founder and editor of Poetry Magazine , visited the group often.

Gladys Campbell and George Dillon (1906-1968) were editors of the Poetry Club's publication, The Forge: A Journal of Verse , published from 1924 to 1929. Campbell and Dillon were close friends for their entire lives and Dillon sent his poems to her for criticism. He was the editor for Poetry Magazine from 1937 to 1949, during which time he also served in WWII. Another close friend of Gladys Campbell's was the writer Glenway Wescott (1901-1987). Charles Bell (1916-), another poet and Assistant Professor of Humanities at the University of Chicago, also sent Campbell drafts of poems for criticism.

Campbell wrote poetry throughout her life and her poems appeared frequently in Poetry, The Forge, The Dial and Book Notes . She published one collection, The Momentary Beach , in 1972. From 1922 to 1929, Campbell taught English in the University of Chicago Lab Schools and from 1929 to 1957 she taught humanities and English at the University of Chicago. She retired in 1957. Campbell was active in Hyde Park's Poetry Society, which met in her apartment. Writers such as Yvor Winters, George Dillon, and Thornton Wilder were among its members. Campbell never married and lived in the Hyde Park section of Chicago until her death in 1992.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Gladys Campbell Papers contain correspondence, writings, and other papers that document the work of the poet Gladys Campbell and friends from the University of Chicago Poetry Club, as well as her relationship with other poets. The papers also contain writings of George Dillon, Charles Bell, Janet Lewis, Maurice Lesemann, Naomi Clark, and Morton Zabel. The papers span the years 1914 to 1995. Correspondence comprises the bulk of the papers and spans 1914 to 1995. Writings by Gladys Campbell and others spans 1924 to 1986 and includes undated material. Photographs and printed materials make up the smallest portion of the papers, spanning 1924 to 1992.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Gladys Campbell Papers are organized into six series: Correspondence, Writings, Writings of Others, Photographs, University of Chicago Materials, and Printed Materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I, Correspondence, is arranged alphabetically by correspondent, with a small amount of third party and unidentified correspondence filed at the end. Correspondence from friends upon the receipt of Campbell's book of poetry, Momentary Beach is grouped together at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence between Gladys Campbell and a number of her friends. The primary correspondents are George Dillon and Glenway Wescott; they discuss Gladys Campbell's and their own poetry throughout their correspondence. Correspondence from George Dillon Janet Lewis includes drafts of their poems.

George Dillon's letters document his decision to work for Poetry Magazine as Associate Editor and his dedication to The Forge , as well as proposed changes to be made to Poetry Magazine under his leadership.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes two photographs of George Dillon and photocopy of Dillon's obituary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes typescript drafts of George Dillon poems:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes typescript draft of George Dillon poem "The Pomegranate" and drawing of Gladys Campbell by George Dillon enclosed with undated letter

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes a signed photocopy of Lewis's "For Emily" and printouts of "For Esther Sills" and "For Clara Atkins on her 91 Birthday."

did.unittitle: Lewis, Janet to Kathleen Foster Campbell

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Writings, contains three groups of poems by Gladys Campbell. The first, labeled by Campbell "Good copies of most best poems," is numbered in order, perhaps in preparation for a book. The second, an intended compilation titled The Shadowed Field , includes poems previously published in Poetry , The Dial , The Forge and Book Notes . The third group is comprised of unpublished poems that Campbell labeled "unpub". The series also includes an "Inventory" of Campbell's teaching, writings and publications.

did.unittitle: "Good copies of most of best poems," drafts, typescript and holograph
The Shadowed Field , draft, typescript, corrected

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III, Writings of Others, is arranged alphabetically by author, with "The Poetry Club of Chicago: Bibliography (Early, Major, Collected)" filed at the end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains writings by Gladys Campbell's friends and fellow members of the University of Chicago Poetry Club, who sent their writings to Campbell for criticism. The bulk is poems by George Dillon, although Glenway Wescott's and Charles Bell's writings are also substantial. Bell's writings often include notes to Campbell in the margins.

did.unittitle: Poems, drafts, holograph and typescript carbon
"A Scene from Faust," draft, typescript, corrected
Clark, Naomi. "Late Autumnal: California" and "Variations on a Theme Dream" drafts, typescript and typescript photocopy

Lewis, Janet. Poems, drafts, typescript, annotated
"I, In My Pitiful Flesh" and "After-Image," drafts, holograph corrected
Zabel, Morton Dauwen, "Herakles Archer," draft, typescript
"The Poetry Club of Chicago: Bibliography (Early, Major, Collected)," typescript photocopy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV, Photographs, is arranged alphabetically by subject.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series V, University of Chicago Materials, is arranged chronologically

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes material relating to Gladys Campbell's work as a student and faculty member at the University of Chicago.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VI, Printed Material, is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes journal reprints, holiday cards, reports, clippings, and a brochure.
